intro: Brassica sinapistrum var. siliqua-hirsuta, commonly known as the hairy siliqua mustard, is a Brassicaceae species characterized by its distinctive hairy leaves and elongated, siliqua-like pods. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with alternate, pinnately lobed leaves that have a rough texture. Its flowers are small, yellow, and arranged in racemes, typical of the mustard family. The siliqua pods are hairy and contain several small, round seeds. This variety is often found in disturbed soils and is an annual herb native to parts of Europe and Asia.
